title: midge-repellents-top-tips-keep-scotlands-biting-beasties-bay
story: IT is a ferocious and much-feared beast, one that has long wreaked misery across Scotland, emerging at dusk ndash or dawn ndash to feast on human blood.The dreaded midge isnt to be trled with. Weve all been there, sitting outside on a warm summers evening and enjoying a sunset, when there comes a tell-tale nip upon exposed flesh. The arm, the leg, the neck, the face, the scalp ndash the midge isnt fussy ndash and before you know it, youre under siege.With more of us set to enjoy staycations this year, we need to learn to coexist with these tiny flying brutes, which is why Im offering up my services as a human guinea pig. Im a good test subject given Ive never met a midge that doesnt like me.I still bear the scars ndash mental and physical ndash of a long weekend in Glen Coe a few years ago. It was July. There was cloud cover, no wind and a sticky humidity. I was almost eaten alive.Scotlands walks are never complete without the dreaded midgeBelieve me, I have tried everything to keep the midges at bay. Among the long list of suggestions that Ive given a whirl are eating Marmite sandwiches, spraying a fine mist of Listerine and taking garlic tablets .Smoke can act as a deterrent, which has seen me huddling next to barbecues and bonfires like they are two-bar electric fires on cold winter mornings.Ive donned midge nets that give me the forlorn air of a beekeeper who has lost her hive, or a grieving Victorian widow. Im considering putting up bat boxes after reading that a lone bat can eat , midges in one night.Citronella and Saltidinare among the ingredients that midges are said to find repugnant and give a wide berth. Essential oils such as eucalyptus, lavender and lemongrass have been credited with similar properties .The midge has a mighty reputation for such a miniscule insect. Weighing just one th of a gram, it has a teeny wingspan of -mm. Midges breed in vast numbers across  per cent of Scotlands land mass.Midges are said to enjoy the smell of our natural body odour and sweat which is where using certain scents can come in handy.Here we test some of the best midge-repelling lotions and potions:Avon Skin So Soft , pound.This moisturiser wasnt designed with midges in mind but has famously been adopted for that purpose. When I interviewed the ultramarathon runner Dean Karnazes in , he mentioned that a friend had advised stocking up on Avon Skin So Soft would be prudent before a visit to Scotland.The Royal Marines are said to swear by its midge-repelling powers when training or based in and around the west coast.The secret to Skin So Soft creating a no-fly zone for midges has been widely attributed to the citronella that it contains.Skin So Soft has been my go-to over the years, clocking up a decent midge-busting hit rate.Application consistency:A dry oil spray.Smell:Baby talcum powder.Verdict:Still a classic. It has won an army of global fans for good reason.Visit avon.ukSmidge , pound.Wandering around shops and supermarkets across the Highlands during the summer months, you will see tourists clutching this elixir.Smidge has been about for a decade now. Its development was led by Dundee-based Dr Alison Blackwell, an authority on midge behaviour and leader of the team behind the Scottish Midge Forecast.The active ingredient is Saltidin which, according to the blurb, "has been molecularly designed to effectively block the antennal receptors of biting insects ndash basically, it throws them off your scent." Smidge is also billed as working on mosquitoes, black flies, sand flies, fleas and ticks.Application consistency:A lightweight, aluminium cannister with pump spray that dispels a fast-absorbing, water-based lotion.Smell:Chic unisex scent. Think CK One.Verdict:Did a stellar job as I sat in my tree-covered garden on a still, humid evening.Visit smidgeupMary Jean Highland Midge Lotion , poundThe idea of making a midge lotion is one that Elizabeth and Mary Quinn struck upon by chance. The owners of family-run Mary Jean in Fochabers, Moray, were selling their skincare products at a Highland Games in .The midges were biting and in a moment of inspiration, Mary soaked some kitchen roll in lemongrass oil and hung it from their stall. It worked a treat and an idea took seed, leading to the creation of Mary Jean Highland Midge Lotion.,params: .pushIngredients include lemongrass ndash of course ndash as well as bog myrtle, aloe vera, jojoba, neem and mango. It is a wholesome product: handmade, organic, palm oil-free, vegan-friendly and non-toxic. Available in a ml travel size. Can also be used to deter mosquitoes and horseflies.Application consistency:A luxurious and light-feeling cream from a pump dispenser.Smell:Delicious citrus overtones.Verdict:A brilliant product that kept me midge-free. It also helped soothe redness on existing bites.Visit maryjeanAnderson Aromatics Beastie Be Gone , poundBeastie Be Gone, which launched in May, was coined by Bothwell-based clinical aromatherapist and perfumer Julie Anderson-McKee.As someone who loves the outdoors ndash Anderson-McKee can often be found camping in a tent or a caravan by a loch ndash she knows only too well the blight of midges.The result is a triple action cream that combines insect repellent, SPF  protection and a moisturiser that can be used as an after sun. It comes with excellent credentials, including being vegan, hypo-allergenic and as Anderson-McKee puts it "free from all nasties".Tried and tested by  Scottish wild campers and walkers, among the ingredients are organic shea butter, coconut and almond oils, lavender, lemon eucalyptus, citronella and myrrh.Application consistency:A sumptuous cream in a sleek metal container.Smell:Pleasant hints of lemon and lavender.Verdict:An impressive new kid on the block that does what it says on the tin.Visit andersonaromatics

title: scotlands-schools-four-key-updates-parents-ahead-reopening
story: PARENTS across Scotland are eagerly anticipating confirmation that schools will go back full time next month.Primary and secondary schools across the country closed their doors back in March to all but a few children.But with coronavirus in Scotland being suppressed to very low levels, things are looking optimistic regarding ato the classroom.Yesterday, education secretary John Swinney provided an update on schools.Here are fourkey things we learned:Teachers:The Scottish Government yesterday announced pound million of funding to employ hundreds of teachers and support staff to help schools reopen.An extra pound million was also pledged to cover other health protection costs.The funding will equate to around  teachers and  support staff.But as Labourrsquos education spokesperson, Iain Gray, pointed out, that accounts for only half a new member of staff per school across Scotland.August   Councils and schools have been working to the August date for some time.But the Scottish Government will not formally announce the August date until July .The Scottish Government has repeatedly stressed that reducing the infection rate is crucial to the reopening of schools, with the First Minister earlier in the week suggesting no more lockdown changes will be made until pupils are back in the classroom.Mr Swinney stressed that in Scotland, the infection rate is ldquoreducing by  per cent each week, but a sudden surge in cases over the next few weeks could sht the Scottish Governmentrsquos confidence that it is safe to re-open schools.Some pupils may have to socially distanceSocial distancingMr Swinney gave parents some much-needed details about the social distancing guidance that schools will be asked to follow ndash but some questions still remain over how this will work in practice.While primary pupils will not have to socially distance when theyon August , all being well, secondary schools will be told to enforce physical distancing rules ldquowhere possible.Mr Swinney said this was due to the scientic advice on social distancing being ldquoless clear for older pupils.Meanwhile secondary schools will be asked to adjust the layout of classrooms and manage flows of people in and out of buildings ndash but with a catch.This social distancing rule in secondary schools will be ldquosubject always to this not reducing capacity within the school.Youth clubsAs well as earmarking pound million for school staff and pound million to help councils meet extra costs in reopening classrooms, pound million of previously announced money will be used to support youth work in connection with schools being reopened.Mr Swinney said this funding has been announced as the sector has ldquocontinued to support and engage children and young people through the pandemic, highlighting the use of digital technology to help mitigate the impact of the lockdown on young peoplersquos mental health.

title: staff-face-redundancy-borders-call-centre--
story: STAFF are facing redundancy at a Galashiels call centre.Sykes has engaged its Nether Road employees in a consultation over their jobs.A Border reader, who said they work at the call centre, told us: "It cant be helped but its devastating to be losing work at a horrible time."A spokesperson for Sykes said: "After careful review we have started consultation about a reduction in the workforce at our Galashiels site."Staff were told about the job losses around three weeks ago, according to the employee who contacted the Border .The employee - who we have granted anonymity - said staff were informed their contracts are coming to an end, with managers also affected."I feel pretty stressed, everyone is feeling the pressure and are worried what to do," the source said.They added: "Theres added stress of finding a job at a time with hardly any jobs available."Some people may be lucky and walk into a new job."Im looking for employment, hoping theres something to take on or Im going to have to seek help from the Job Centre."The source also revealed that the redundancy talks are having an impact on the mental health of some staff."Ive spoken to others and theyre all struggling - their mood is very low, the source said, adding: "People with houses, kids or mortgages are going to struggle.A Sykes spokesperson said: "Sykes is responsive to the needs of the market and our clients in a constantly changing business landscape."The decision to make such changes is never easy."After careful review we have started consultation about a reduction in the workforce at our Galashiels site."The Border has contacted the company to ask how many jobs will be lost.Have you been affected by redundancy talks in the Borders  Get in touch by emailing: editorial@bordertelegraph

title: face-masks-scotland-two-key-mistakes-everyone-making
story: TODAY marks two weeks since face coverings became mandatory in shops across Scotland.So far, just one person has been handed a pound fine for not complying with the rules ndash as the country tries to further control the suppression of the coronavirus.The Scottish Government says that in enclosed spaces, where physical distancing is more dficult with people who are not members of your household, you should wear a face covering.By law, you must wear a covering in shops and on public transport ndash with similar rules coming into force in England today.But there are some parts of the guidance that many people seem to be forgetting.They are:When applying or removing the covering, it is important that you wash sanitise your handsfirst and avoid touching your face.After EACH USE, you must wash the face covering at  degrees centigrade or dispose of it safely.Who is exempt from wearing a covering Some people are not required to wear a face covering.These include:Children under fiveyears of age.Police constables or workers such as paramedics acting in the course of their duty.Staff such as drivers or checkout assistants who are physically separated, by means of, for example, screens, from passengers or customers.Shop workersthey maintain a two-metre distance from customers or members of the public.You are required by law to wear a face covering in Scotlands shops and on public transport .Find out how you can #StaySafeand protect others ##mdash Scottish GovernmentJuly , You may also have a reasonable excuse not to wear a face covering , for example:You have a health condition or you are disabled and a face covering would be inappropriate because it would cause dficulty, pain or severe distress or anxiety or because you cannot apply a covering and wear it in the proper manner safely and consistently.Inidual discretion should be applied in considering the use of face coverings for other children including, for example, children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who would struggle to wear a face covering.You need to eat or drink.You are taking medication.You are communicating with someone  who relies on lip reading.A relevant person, such as a police officer, asks you to remove your face covering.

title: 13-unusual-quirky-places-holiday-scotland
story: IF you are looking for a staycation that stokes the imagination, Scotland has no shortage of unusual and quirky gems.With the nationrsquos tourism sector now reopened, wersquove put together a list of some of our favourite awe-inspiring holiday accommodation.Places that bring together architectural wizardry and painstaking refurbishment to breathe new le ndash and use ndash into everything from a lighthouse to a modern-day broch and erstwhile modes of transportation, including buses, train carriages and even a helicopter.Roulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersThere is something wonderfully romantic about this circle of seven colourful roulotteslocated in a pretty wildflower meadow below the Eildon Hills.Each roulotte faces onto a lochan at the centre of the site. Facilities include sunset decks, wood-burning stoves, eco saunas and hot tubs. Itrsquos a perfect getaway for nature lovers with owls, deer, foxes, and badgers among the regular visitors.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit roulotteretreatHelicopter Glamping, Mains Farm Wigwams, Thornhill, StirlingStay in a Sea King helicopter complete with mini kitchen, bathroom and a cockpit seating area offering stunning views over the Forth Valley. The helicopter ndash part of Mains Farm Wigwams ndash sleeps two adults or a family of five . Therersquos a double bed, a single bed in the tail and seating which converts into a second double bed. The owners are currently renovating a  Scottish Aviation Twin Pioneer plane set to open for overnight stays next year.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit mainsfarmwigwamsSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandChoose between a vintage railway carriage, a freight wagon or the Waiting Room BB.Located beside a ing train station at Rogart , Sleeperzzz offers budget accommodation for backpackers, families, walkers, cyclists or those who simply fancy spending the night somewhere a bit dferent ndash such as a -ton goods van from the s.A great base for exploring Dunrobin Castle and the North Coast .Prices from poundpp per night. Call   or visit sleeperzzzCraighead Howfs, Dunblane, PerthshireBe transported to The Shire ndash which could be Perthshire or JRR Tolkienrsquos fictional Middle-earth in The Lord of the Rings, depending on how you look at it ndash with these magical Hobbit Howfs.The Burrow and Bagend are built into the hillside with grassy roofs and round doors for an unforgettable glamping experience. Craighead Howfs also offers the chance to stay in a treehouse with panoramic views over the Ochils and a secluded summer house.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit craigheadhowfThe Bus Stop, Gford, East LothianIf you have ever wanted to enjoy a Summer Holiday in the vein of the  film, look no further. This fleet of buses in a field belonging to an arable farm in East Lothian have been transformed into holiday accommodation with armchairs, sofas, lanterns, hot flasks, log stoves and beds.Each bus has a private wood-fired hot tub and barbecue fire pit. Choose from rustic or luxury ndash the latter have en suite bathrooms and swish mod cons. Oh, and therersquos gorgeous views of the Lammermuir Hills.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit thebusstop.scotBrockloch Eco Retreat, Kirkpatrick Durham, Castle DouglasFeatured on George Clarkersquos Amazing Spaces, Brockloch Eco Retreat is small but perfectly formed. Located on a working farm, therersquos two units: a contemporary, off-grid, micro-timber bothy facing into an open field and an incredible treehouse hideaway within a bluebell wood where the closest neighbours are red squirrels.The treehouse has a built-in double bed with a skylight to gaze at the treetops and stars as you drt off to sleep. This part of the world is a great place to see red kites.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit brocklochBlack Isle Yurts, Eathie Hill, RosemarkieSet in private woodland, all of the yurts within this eco-sensitive, wild-glamping site are based on designs used by nomadic people in Central Asia for thousands of years.In keeping with the Scottish climate, the traditional felt outer shell has been replaced with a waterproof canvas and therersquos a wood-burning stove to stay cosy on cooler nights. The site is a short drive from Chanonry Point which is fantastic for dolphin spotting.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit blackisleyurtsRua Reidh Lighthouse, near Gairloch, Wester RossBuilt in  by David Alan Stevenson, a cousin of the writer Robert Louis Stevenson and one of the famous ldquoLighthouse Stevensons, this beautul, remote location offers BB and self-catering, the latter in the charmingly named First Officerrsquos Quarters.Endless views, a glorious stretch of coastline, abundant bird and sea le, tranquillity, solitude and the thrill of potentially catching a glimpse of the Aurora Borealis on dark, starry nights awaits.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit stayatalighthouseCalgary, MullNot to be confused with the skyscraper-filled city in Alberta, this little corner of Mull is a delight.A byre, hayloft and dovecote are among the self-catering properties available at Calgary, each with its own distinctive character. Calgary also has an excellent cafe, art gallery and a woodland sculpture walk.Therersquos a beach within strolling distance where Robinrsquos Boat sells Isle of Mull ice cream. Sea eagles, otters and basking sharks can all be seen nearby.,params: .pushPrices start from pound for a seven-night stay. Call   or visit calgaryThe Scriptorium Apartments at St Benedictrsquos Abbey, Fort AugustusThe Scriptorium ndash the once secret writing room of the monastery ndash has two one-bedroom apartments with vaulted ceilings, gothic archways and stained-glass windows. Therersquos plenty to do in the grounds and gardens, be it tennis, badminton, croquet or giant chess. The former Monksrsquo Refectory has been converted into a Club Lounge and a chapel refurbished to incorporate a heated pool, sauna and steam room.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit parrandierThe Brochs of Coigach, near Achiltibuie, UllapoolBrochs are an ancient dwelling found only in Scotland, dating back to BC. Gille Buidhersquos Broch and Scalrsquos Broch are a bit younger than thatand beautully enchanting structures.If you love upcycling, they will impress, built using stones from old, crumbling walls on nearby land and timber recovered from a dilapidated Victorian pier. Oil paintings by John Bellany hang on the walls, alongside display cabinets filled with weird and wonderful objects.Prices from pound per night. Call   or visit thebrochsThe Four Sisters Boatel, EdinburghTucked away in the heart of the Scottish capital, this houseboat is permanently moored at the Lochrin Basin on the Union Canal ndash the eastern terminus for the -mile stretch of water that comes all the way from Falkirk. Sleeping up to six adults and two children, it is an ideal base to explore Edinburgh, with Bruntsfield and the West End, as well as the Old and New Towns, all just a stonersquos throw away.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit thefoursistersThe Sawmill at Glen Dye, Banchory, AberdeenshireTalk about enjoying the great outdoors in style. Stay in a sleek, refurbished s Airstream Safari caravan in a small pine wood beside the fast flowing lade of a sawmill.A rustic, wooden seed store with roots back to the s serves as the kitchen, dining and sitting room. There are games, books, a record player and a memorable barbecue spot. Glen Dye also offers a river cabin, a bothy and two steading cottages, as well as running residential courses in crafts and wild food.Prices start from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit glendyecabinsandcottages

title: author-chris-lloyd-were-surrounded-magic
story: CHILDRENrsquoS author Chris Lloyd says lockdown makes it feel like ldquosomeone has switched the gravity off.The Kent-based non-fiction writer spoke to the Border ahead of his turn at the virtual version of the Borders Book Festival, the physical event having been cancelled due to coronavirus.When not grappling with zero-gravity, Lloyd, , has spent the last  years writing books for children, inspired by nature and the history of the world beyond humans.Discussing his  release, Humanimal, Lloyd said: "Children are born with an instinct, an intuition that all living things are connected and that theyre part of an ecosystem."This is the way we are naturally but society and culture tend to beat that out of us ndash they tell us were more intelligent."The point of the book is to try to preserve, for children, this reality of interconnectivity, and to give them some protection to whats happened to us adults over the years.ldquoWhich is the inevitable feeling that we are what matters and that everything  is there to serve us or for us to use or exploit."We cant continue with that mindset as a species and survive."As this is the message he is keen to share, Humanimaland Lloyds other works are not designed to act as an "A to Z encyclopaedia" of information, but rather tell the planets natural history away from the impact of humanity."All my books are meant for adults as well as children," said Lloyd. ldquoTheyre illustrated and designed in a way that makes adults want to buy them for children and I hope children want to share them with adults."Its a book, its a story, its something to be discussed, its something to be read out loud, its something to be looked at together.ldquoIts not a book and a child, its really something to open doors as much as anything ."And Lloyd believes, as much magic as there is in fiction, non-fiction ndash and the content that inspires it ndash can hold just as much whimsy.He said: "For me non-fiction has always been the more magical part of literature. There are a lot of young people for whom the real world is more amazing than anything you could make up."Again, thats another thing were born with that gets beaten out of us, and we start using the word ordinary ndash and theres nothing ordinary."Were surrounded by magic. You think Harry Potters magic  Just look around you."That curiosity is our biggest asset because thats how we learn to adapt, thats how we learn to survive, thats how we learn to cope with the world around us as it changes."Lloyd, who previously worked as a Sunday Timesjournalist, was inspired to begin a career as a childrens author after seeing the joy his children experienced when they learnt new things during their years in home-schooling.Particularly that of one of his daughters who was astonished to learn all about Antarctica ndash home of her then favourite animal, the penguin."I believe fundamentally, especially now having done thousands of talks in schools and festivals over the last  years, that humans generally reach peak curiosity at the age of nine or ," Lloyd said."Then things start to get in the way, like puberty and your friendship groups change and going from primary to secondary school."But at the age of nine or  youve got that purity of curiosity where youre old enough to know that you have an identity and youre curious enough to want to know where you fit in."Theres nothing you cant talk to a nine or -year-old about ndash provided you dont patronise them, provided you dont have an expectation of them that they cant meet."If you can meet them as fellow kindred spirits on this rock travelling around the sun, in this incredible galaxy, and here we are, face to face, learning about it and discovering things together, then there is nothing more inspiring than engaging with a nine or -year-old."Chris Lloyds Humanimalbook event will be broadcast on Sunday, July  at am as part of the festivals Family Series, and will include a discussion portion after a short presentation by Lloyd.The event is suitable for families with children aged seven and over.

title: sykes-redundancies-john-lamont-seeks-meeting-bosses
story: BORDERS MP John Lamont is seeking an ldquourgent meeting with call centre bosses following news of redundancies in Galashiels.Sykes employees face losing their jobs at Nether Road.Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, described the looming redundancies as ldquodevastating.He said: ldquoThis is an already very uncertain and stressful time for many people so it will be particularly dficult for those workers affected.A Sykes spokespersontold the Border on July  that staff are being consulted about job losses.But some employees later approached this newspaper to say every worker has been told their last day will be at the end of August, when the entire call centre will close.Sykes has been contacted for further comment.Mr Lamont said: ldquoThe reports of these redundancies at the Sykes call centre is devastating.ldquoThis is an already very uncertain and stressful time for many people so it will be particularly dficult for those workers affected.ldquoSykes are a big employer in the Borders so these job losses will add further challenges for our local economy as it begins to recover from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoI am seeking an urgent meeting with the management team to see what support can be provided.ldquoFor anybody who is worried about their job and is looking for advice, I would encourage them to contact me and I will do my best to assist.

title: borders-book-festival-2020-line-up-august-announced
story: DAVID Baldacci, Sara Pascoe and Sebastian Barry are among the stars appearing at the online Borders Book Festival in August.The online edition of the festival, which launched on July , offers free-to-view talks every week.The line-up for August has now been unveiled, with festival director Alistair Moffat hailing a ldquodynamic schedule.Mr Moffat said: ldquoWersquove been delighted with the positive response wersquove received since the virtual festival launched this month and are excited to reveal a lively and eclectic line-up for August.Former Love Islandcontestant Camilla Thurlow is among the guests due to appear.Others include crime writer Val McDermid, broadcaster Sally Magnusson and childrenrsquos author Alan Windram ndash who is from Galashiels.This is the full line-up for AugustSunday, August am: Alan Windram will be launching the latest title from his award-winning picture book series One Button Bennypm: Broadcaster and novelist Sally Magnusson on myth, immortality and the role of women in society with festival director Alistair Moffatpm: US bestselling thriller writer David Baldacci talks to Lee Randall about his latest novel A Minute to MidnightSunday, August am: Hilarious adventures from Wigglesbottom Primary with Pamela Butchartpm: Dutch historian Rutger Bregman presents a new view on human naturepm: Award-winning novelist Sebastian Barry on his latest novel A Thousand MoonsSunday, August am: Eilidh Muldoon will show young viewers how to draw a very sleepy owl in this launch event for Snooze.pm: Environmental campaigner Jonathon Porritt presents a compelling blueprint for post-COVID - recoverypm: Former Bishop of Edinburgh, and bestselling author Richard Holloway helping us to make sense of the world with writer and broadcaster Sally MagnussonThursday, August pm: The riotously funny comedian Sara Pascoe will be joining the festival with an exclusive midweek special event on modern masculinity and sexual economicsSunday rd Augustam: Fun facts and drawing tips from master cartoonist Gary Northfield, the creator of the hilarious Julius Zebra bookspm: How to change the world with young activist and entrepreneur Jeremiah Emmanuelpm: Unrivalled queen of crime Val McDermid on her latest heart-pounding thriller Still LeSunday, August am: Much-loved Sir Charlie Stinky Socks author, Kristina Stephensonpm: Reflections on celebrity culture and mental health with Camilla Thurlow and her inspirational new memoir Not The Typepm: Dr Amir Khan, from Channel rsquos Behind Closed Doors, talks about his brand-new book The Doctor Will See You Now and tells us how he helped lead one of the busiest GP surgeries in the country through the unprecedented trials of the COVID pandemic.All events from the July programme are still available to view for free at any time from the festival website www.bordersbookfestival.org

title: borders-football-fans-tell-stories-new-book
story: FOOTBALL fans from Galashiels are featured in new book examining rivalries from around the world.Us and Them: New Journeys in Football Rivalry is published by anti-sectarian charity Nil By Mouth.As well as including accounts from Bilbao, China and Kosovo, the book tells the stories of Tam Cass and Johnny Sweeney, who watched their teams compete in the tragic Ibrox Stadium Disaster fixture of  where  fans lost their lives.The chapter lsquoCity Rivalsrsquo was written by Nil by Mouth director Dave Scott, who lives in the Borders.He said: ldquoFootball rivalry, especially when it comes to the lsquoOld Firmrsquo, is a cocktail of pride, passion, pantomime and poison.ldquoIt would be easy to focus on the negatives but we choose to look at some interesting stories of friendship across the ide, both on and off the pitch, examining the relationship between [Celticrsquos] Billy McNeill and [Rangers player] John Greig as well as allowing supporters the opportunity to tell their own stories.ldquoTam and Johnnyrsquos story is an extremely powerful one as it shows how they could easily set aside sporting rivalry when faced which much deeper human experiences.Writers who have contributed to the book include Daniel Gray and Andrew Downie.Visit nilbymouth.org for more information.

title: border
story: AN MSP is calling for Borderers to be mindful of those who cannot wear face coverings for medical reasons.The masks became mandatory in shops and on public transport several weeks ago.But there are exemptions, such as people with a health condition or living with a disability.And Borders MSP Rachael Hamilton is encouraging retailers, shopkeepers and the general public to be considerate and to adhere to the two-metre social distancing rule when near people without a covering.She said: ldquoWe need to all look out for each other at this dficult time.ldquoWearing face coverings in shops reduces the risk of transmission but we must be mindful that not everyone can wear one.ldquoSome people with medical conditions or disabilities are unable to wear face coverings, and we must recognise that they will require more personal space when moving around shops.ldquoThat is why, regardless of face coverings, to remain at a safe distance from people in shops and enclosed spaces."The British Lung Foundation has produced a downloadable graphic that people can show on their phones to explain why they arenrsquot wearing a face covering.The card aims to inform staff when entering shops and supermarkets, and on public transport.Sarah MacFadyen, head of policy at Asthma UK and the British Lung Foundation, said: ldquoItrsquos important to wear a face covering where advised not only to protect yourself but others around you, who could be more vulnerable to COVID-."However, we need a greater awareness that there are exemptions from the rules on face coverings, and this includes people with severe respiratory conditions."Most people will be able to wear a face covering with no problem, but some people find that wearing a mask makes them feel like they canrsquot breathe.Visit www.blf.org.uk to download the graphic.

title: msps-call-signs-display-virus-advice-cross-border-routes
story: THREE MSPs have written to transport bosses in a bid to get the latest COVID- advice displayed on electronic road signs in the Borders.Last week, Christine Grahame and fellow SNP politicians Emma Harper and Joan McAlpine sent as joint letter to the chief executives of Transport Scotland and Highways England.They want the information boards on cross-border routes to highlight the dferences in coronavirus restrictions.The MSPs said some of their constituents were "concerned" that visitors coming into the region from other parts of the UK were unfamiliar with the dferences in the COVID- rules.And that the confusion had even caused "animosity" with local businesses and residents.Christine Grahame, MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, said: "While I welcome people coming to visit the Borders ndash world-renowned for its history and outstanding scenery ndash we want to ensure that people enjoy the area safely and understand that in Scotland we have our own approach to easing the COVID- restrictions, which dfers from the approach taken by other parts of the UK."To this end, we have jointly written to the chief executives of Transport Scotland and Highways England to request that electronic road signage on cross-border routes between the two nations reflect the dferences in COVID- restrictions.ldquoScotland has made excellent progress towards stopping the spread of COVID-, and now as we are starting to see more of our tourism, leisure and hospitality businesses open, we want to ensure this good progress continues while keeping local communities safe.ldquoOne way to inform people is by ensuring that everyone is aware of the measures which are in place in Scotland, as they head north, and England as they head south, which we encourage everyone to follow.ldquoWe look forward to hearing back from both Transport Scotland and Highways England soon.

title: big-changes-furlough-scheme-august-1----need-know
story: MAJOR changes to the furlough scheme are to come this week.Employers across the UK have until Friday to submit claims for furloughed staff for periods ending on or before June .The UK Government introduced new rules at the start of the month, allowing furloughed employees back to work for any amount of time or sht pattern.Employers would pay the wages for those days, with the UK Government still pay the % grant ndash up to a cap of pound per month ndash on the days not worked.But from Saturday, August , more major changes are to come into effect.What are the changes From Saturday, the level of grant will be reduced each month until the scheme ends on October .Chancellor Rishi SunakWhat does this mean for employers From this date, employers will be required to start contributing more eachmonth.They will also have to start paying National Insurance Contributions and pension contributions for the hours the employee is on furlough.From September , employers will be made to contribute % towards the wage payments ndash which will be added on to % provided by the UK Government.And From October , employers will have to contribute %, added on to % by the UK Government.Full details can be found here.What does this mean for furloughed staff The good news for you is that your wages will remain the same.You will continue to receive % of your salary ndash but the dference is just the adjustment of what your employer pays, and what the state pays.How many people are furloughed in Scotland According to figures published on July , nearly , people in Scotland have been helped by the furlough and self-employment support schemes.UK government figures show that, up to the end of June, , Scots had been furloughed.In addition, another , claims have been made to the scheme supporting self-employed workers during the lockdown period.What is the new timetable Here is the new furlough timetable, as set out by the UK Government:What do the experts say Martin Lewis at the MoneySavingExpert websitesays there could be ldquoserious consequence of this timetable.He said: ldquoIf your employer doesnt believe your role will be viable,it needs to start paying for it, theres a chance that this escalation of employment costs for the employer could tip it over the edge in seeking it to make employees redundant.ldquoWe hope this wont happen, but there is a chance.

title: gala-fairydean-rovers-rename-bar-legend-volunteer
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers have re-named the bar in their clubrooms after volunteer Alan Allison.The new signs unveiling took place in the clubrooms on Sunday for his th birthday.For almost a decade Alan has manned the bar voluntarily every weekend serving refreshments to members and visitors.Apart from the current pandemic which forced the closure of the bar from March, he has only missed one sht ndash a Saturday in May  when he was at Hampden to see Hibernian lt the Scottish Cup.Gala Fairydean Rovers chairman Ryan Cass said:"Alan is a legend at the club and no-one deserves this more than him."With his th birthday coming up this week, we felt it was appropriate to re-name the bar in his honour."The Alan Allison bar reopened last weekend.Meanwhile on the playing front Gala Fairydean Rovers first team resume training this weekend so they will be fully prepared for the new Lowland League campaign which is expected to get underway at the start of October.

title: galashiels-author-alan-windram-set-borders-book-festival
story: ROBOT dancing, singalongs and an exclusive look inside One Button Bennysnew adventure are all in store this weekend.Author Alan Windram, who is originally from Galashielsis bringing the second instalment of the award-winning story to the Borders Book Festival in the first reading of the to-be-released picture book.And Windram has ensured the region is front and centre with this book.Although set in space, talented Borderers have helped with the creation of the story."Basically, I wrote it Chloe [Holwill-Hunter] illustrated it, and weve got Jack Lowden who has read the audiobook for us," he explained."Jack read the audiobook for the first book, and hes also kindly read the audiobook for the second book."Windrams connections to his collaborators go back years, as he met Lowden while performing in local amateur dramatics groups.Holwill-Hunter was a classmate of Lowdens when they were schoolchildren.When askedbringing Borders talent to the fore was part of his writing plans, Windram said that initially, it was serendipitous to work with Holwill-Hunter.He said: "Jacks mum, at the time, ran the Flat Cat Cafeacute in Lauder, we used to go there and Chloe was a waitress there."I saw some of the illustrations she had done and thought, wow these are amazing, it would be lovely to do a picture book ndash so it all happened by chance."We [with Holwill-Hunter] did our first picture book called a Puppys Taletogether and then after that we did the first One Button Benny."I knew Jack through the Gala Opera. So I thought, why dont I seeJack will read the audiobook, so it all kind of happened by chance."One Button Benny, and even the storys sequel, One Button Benny and the Gigantic Catastrophe, all come with le lessons for their young readers, something which Windram was keen to include in his writing."All the books I write have some kind of moral emphasis," he added. "The story of One Button Benny, well the first one, was about a little robot who gets bullied and teased."Kids can often relate to that, although its a robot, they can relate to that as things that happen."The first book is very much about that everybody is special and everybody is unique, everybody has something to give as well."The second book takes it a little bit further, continuing with those themes, but also its about friendship. Its about working together, but its also about saying sorry when maybe something happens or you do something wrong."Alan Windrams book event, Bennys Back, will be streamed live on Sunday, August  at am via the Borders Book Festival, where he will perform two original songs about Benny, two readings, including an exclusive look at the new One Button Benny and the Gigantic Catastrophe, all with the then sunny Highlands as a backdrop.For more information on the event, with links to other events during the festivals Family Series, visit: bordersbookfestival.org online-event alan-windram-bennys-back

title: former-polish-shop-galashiels-converted-housing
story: AN APPLICATION to turn a former grocery store in Galashiels into two homes has been given the green light.The Polish Shop, at  High Street, will be turned into a flat and a two-storey house.Scottish Borders Councils lead planning officer Carlos Clarke said that although the shop was in the town centre, it was "well outwith the Core Activity Area".He added: "I recognise the loss of the retail use, but also note the building has had non-retail uses in the recent past ."I accept the residential use may be a less vibrant contributor to the town centre, and that there are no other ground floor residential uses fronting the High Street."However, a residential use will, nonetheless, be a positive contributor, and this shop comprises an unremarkable and modest property located at the end of the town centre, well away from the principal activity area of the town."There is also a range of uses in this part of town already, including residential uses on upper floors."A residential use on the ground floor would have a negligible effect on the strength of the town centre overall and the character of this end of the town, and would maintain the mixed use nature of this area."

title: stunning-570k-airdrie-mansion-sauna-grabs-2-50-raffle-competition

title: vans-trailers-given-green-light-recycling-centres
story: VANS and trailers will now be given access to Borders recycling centres on an appointment basis.Launching today, Scottish Borders Councilhas created an online booking system which will allow owners of large vans and trailers to transport waste to local recycling centres.This new development is part of SBCs phasedto its normal recycling and waste disposal services.Chief executive at SBC, Tracey Logan, said: "We know that owners of large vans and trailers have been keen to start using recycling centres again for a number of weeks, and we thank them for their patience."Bookings for large van, or trailer disposals can be made up to a week in advance or with a minimum of two days notice. Commercial access is still not granted.Large vans, such as a Ford Transit, are defined as being two tonnes in weight when carrying the maximum permitted load. Small  vans, such as a Ford Courier, do not need to book in advance.The free booking system noties householders that they should arrive promptly to their booked slot, however,there is a queue they will still be granted access, even after their allotted time.Borderers are asked not to queue beyond signs at entrances to avoid unnecessary queueing.If vehicles arrive at a centre with no booking, they will not be allowed entry.The pre-existing waste quantity restrictions remain in place - a maximum of five bin bags of waste including a limit of two large items.Other restrictions, such as one householder per visit is allowed to exit a vehicle, and staff are unable to offer help to remove waste from vehicles.Ms Logan added: "We know that owners of large vans and trailers have been keen to start using recycling centres again for a number of weeks, and we thank them for their patience.ldquoWe need to ensure we minimised signicant delays and potential social distancing issues for public and staff using the sites, which is why we have been working on a booking system which is now ready to use.ldquoAll large van and trailer owners must make a booking before arriving at a recycling centre. The booking form is straightforward to use and will take five minutes to complete.ldquoOur recycling centres remain very busy andthere is a considerable queue the public is asked to consider coming back to a site at another time.For more information, including opening times and the online booking form for large vans and trailers, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk recyclingcentres

title: galashiels-business-park-sold-8-6m
story: A BUSINESS park in Galashiels has been sold for pound. million.It was announced today that M Real Estate has bought the Galabank Business and Trade Park at Wilderhaugh.The complex currently hosts firms such as Kyowa Kirin International PLC, Momentum Scotland, CubeLtd, Jewson, City Plumbing Supplies, City Electrical Factors, Rexel UK and Dingbro.Jamie Thain of Galbraith, who concluded the sale on behalf of Abercastle Investments, said: ldquoThe investment attracted good interest due to its signicance within the location, quality of accommodation and strong tenant line up."It not only provides high quality modern office accommodation within the town but has also attracted many of the UKrsquos largest trade counter operators who have clustered within the park and trade well from it due to Galashielsrsquo central geographical location within the Scottish Borders."It is a clear example of continued investor appetite for well-presented investments with ongoing asset management potential, even in these unprecedented times.

title: lane-closed-jedburgh-new-crossing
story: ONE lane of the A in Jedburgh at the Abbey Bridge End junction will be closed from Friday for a new pedestrian crossing and resurfacing work.The lane will be closed from .pm on July  until am on August .A spokesperson from Amey, who monitor Borders trunk roads said: "These essential works, with a value of pound,, will improve safety and connectivity for pedestrians and wheelchair users, as well as improving the ride quality for road users at this location."The safety of workers remains a top priority during this essential maintenance project. title: coronavirus-people-scotland-can-take-part-covid-19-vaccine-trial
story: PEOPLE in Scotland are being encouraged to take part in coronavirus vaccine trials.Speaking at the Scottish Governments daily briefing yesterday,Deputy chief medical officer Nicola Steedman asked members of the public to consider whether they could volunteer during the testing phase of the drug.Last week, findings from the early phases of a vaccine being created by Oxford University were published, with Ms Steedman saying the vaccine was both safe and created a ldquogood response in the more than  test subjects.She added: ldquoItrsquos still early days, but itrsquos definitely good news.Ms Steedman said: ldquoScience and research has never been more important than it is now.How can I help Larger-scale trials will be required to ensure that vaccines can be rigorously tested in the coming months and Ms Steedman has said a registry has been set up across the UK for people to sign up to be a part of Covid- trials.Ms Steedman said, adding: ldquoPlease do visit the online siteyou can and think about whether you, like so many others, can volunteer to help with vaccine trials.Online sign-up can be found at www.nhs.uk researchcontactIf you are interested in volunteering for #COVIDvaccine studies, you can register and find out more at https:t.co ZYZzEbIhttps:t.co WhQfkZSsmdash Nicola SturgeonJuly , What  was said at the briefing The First Minister confirmedanother four positive cases of the virusin Scotland, bringing the total to ,.No deaths have been recorded in the last  hours, meaning the total number of fatalities remains at .But NicolaSturgeon said the Scottish Government is likely to adopt a ldquocautious approach to lockdown easing when its planned review takes place on Thursday.She warned there is a ldquoworrying resurgence of Covid cases globally and stressed the hospitality sector in Scotland must ensure it is adhering to guidelines put in place.

title: peebles-shop-owner-irene-says-fond-farewell-customers
story: AFTER nearly four decades in business, Peebles shop owner Irene Ruffell is saying a fond farewell to staff and customers.Irene has spent more than half of her le serving the town after she, and late husband Stuart, opened up their Spar grocery store in Rosetta Road in .Three years later they opened the Glen Road branch.And they successfully ran both shops before selling the Rosetta Road store in .Stuart died in , and Irene credits her loyal staff who she calls her ldquofriends for comforting her through this dficult time in her le.Recalling some of their fond and funny memories over the years, Irene and Stuart did more for their customers than bag groceries.Irene said: ldquoMany years ago when we were at Rosetta Road we had to help a wee old lady. The clip to the suspender belt of her stockings snapped."Luckily Irene managed to save the pensionerrsquos modesty by fashioning together a clip to fix the wardrobe mal.ldquoOn another occasion we fixed a hearing aid for an elderly man who came into the shop. All part of the service! she joked.The couple loved helping their customers, and on many occasions, when elderly residents wondered into the shop from Dunwhinny Care Home, they would personally walk them back to the nursing home complex.Irene added: ldquoSome of our older customers will simply pop in for a wee chat when they were feeling lonely and it was nice to be there for them all of these years."Asked what she plans to do in her retirement, Irene said: ldquoAbsolutely nothing ndash for a while anyway! But Irsquom sure Irsquoll be called upon for babysitting duties as I have two grandchildren and another on the way.The -year-old had planned to jet off on holiday with family to celebrate her retirement, but COVID- meant they had to cancel their plans.As for a socially distanced retirement celebration, Irene said: ldquoIrsquove nothing planned. Irsquoll just slip out of the door quietly I think.Irene is passing the shop keys to Adam Purves Galashiels Ltd on Wednesday, August .As she closes the shop door and opens one to a new chapter in her le, we asked Irene how she feels about saying farewell.She said: ldquoI feel quite emotional. There will definitely be a tear in my eye as my memories and my le with Stuart are in that shop. But itrsquos time, time to say goodbye and thank you to everyone for their custom and friendship over the last  years.

title: harry-dunns-family-scatter-ashes-final-goodbye-holiday-site
story: The family of Harry Dunn are to say their ldquofinal goodbye to the teenager by scattering his ashes in his favourite place.The -year-old motorcyclist has been the subject of an international controversy since he was killed in a road crash in August last year.His mother Charlotte Charles and father Tim Dunn told the PA news agency they had decided to scatter his ashes in Weymouth, Dorset, where the Dunns took their annual family holidays.July   was the last day the teenager was in his favourite town, and Mrs Charles described Wednesday as ldquothe hardest day wersquove ever had to face in our lives.vw,vw,px, px"Charlotte and Bruce Charles Mrs Charles and Mr Dunn, alongside their partners Bruce and Tracey and other extended family members, travelled down to say goodbye to the teenager.Mrs Charles said that although it will feel like they are ldquosetting him free, the ldquofighting will continue to get US suspect Anne Sacoolas back to the UK.Askedher sonrsquos funeral provided any closure, Mrs Charles told PA: ldquoNo, and we were really numb back then ndash very much a bunch of zombies, to put it mildly.ldquoWe donrsquot remember a lot about the first few weeks at all. Obviously wersquove been through so much since then ndash wersquove been to hell and back on many, many occasions.ldquoWersquore not numb any more, we just hurt all day every day. The hurt is there constantly and it never, ever goes away.ldquoBut now,  months on, today is going to be the hardest day wersquove ever had to face in our lives, and I canrsquot imagine it getting any harder.ldquoYou shouldnrsquot have to scatter your own childrsquos ashes.vw,vw,px, px"Tim Dunn with his we Tracey and family spokesman Radd Seiger Mr Dunn said he hoped the family could ldquohave peace after scattering the ashes.Asked why they picked Weymouth, he told PA: ldquoFrom a very early age, Tracey and I first came with Harry and Niall to Weymouth on our first family holiday back in , and every year we would come back on the same week.ldquoIt became a tradition, and as we know poor Harry died last year and today is exactly the last day he was here ndash he came for a night with his friendshellip so itrsquos a year to the day since he was last in Weymouth and wersquore here to scatter his ashes and let him ride free.Mrs Charles added: ldquoWe can rest assured that hersquos definitely out there riding the skies and going everywhere that he wants to go.ldquoWersquove found a beautul spot where we are going to take him and wersquore sure thatthe wind will carry his ashes and the waves will be splashing up on the rocks to help him travel too.ldquoSo wersquoll feel like wersquove set him free.Commenting on what is next for the family, Mrs Charles said: ldquoProper closure. Which is to make sure that Anne Sacoolas goes through the UK justice system. That has to happen.ldquoYou and I would have had to have done it ndash in my view she is no dferent.ldquoSo we will keep fighting ndash today is going to be extremely tough, but the determination never wavers, ever.ldquoIt doesnrsquot matter what today takes out of us, tomorrow will be yet another day of fighting. Today is just for us but the fighting will continue.Askedthey had been able to properly grieve, Mrs Charles said: ldquoI donrsquot think wersquove been able to grieve properly at all.ldquoOf course there are days that are really, really bad and you donrsquot want to see anyone and you just want to cry.ldquoThere are days that are just so overwhelming that we havenrsquot had time to properly grieve. title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having title: community-praised-racing-returns-musselburgh-racecourse
story: Musselburgh Racecourse saw racing resume behind closed doors at two events at the start of the month and held a third event recently.The move involved introducing security measures around the course, which is on Common Good land, to protect the public, racecourse staff and visitingjockeys.The land on which the racecourse operates is a popular walking spot for locals and dog walkers,with neighbouring lagoons.Bill Farnsworth, racecourse general manager, said the course had received huge support from local residents as it sought to ensure fixtures could be held safely and meet health and safety standards.Ahead of the inaugural meeting, the racecourse put in place a lsquoGreen Zonersquo which ensured admission to the grounds was controlled and monitored to minimise the risk posed by Covid-.Safety barriers were erected at points around the course on Linkfield Road and stewards advised local residents where to access the course without encroaching on the Green Zone.Other measures included all attendees completing a compulsory Covid- education module, an online health questionnaire, providing personal details and photo ID, and on arrival undergoing temperature checks by qualied medical staff.Mr Farnsworth said the protocols had been agreed in advance with East Lothian Councilrsquos Safety Advisory Groupand the British Horseracing Authority in order to meet safety guidelines introduced by the Scottish Government.He said: ldquoWe understand the new procedures may have caused some inconvenience to local residents and we will refine the process when Covid- regulations are relaxed.ldquoWe do appreciate the continued support of the local community in bringing racing back to Musselburgh.ldquoThe purpose of the controlled measures is to ensure the safety of the participants on each race day and the safety of the local community, and we are acting on feedback received from local residents following the first two meetings.ldquoWe have placed additional signage on Linkfield Road to ensure the public who use the links and lagoons for recreation and dog walking are fully aware of the access areas during future race days.ldquoOur aim is to provide as much public access to the grounds surrounding the racecourse as possible, whilst operating a safe sporting event.

title: special-tv-appearance-family-tiktok-marathon
story: Eight-year-old Mary Kidd, mum Karen, dad Gordon and older sister Abbie, , appeared on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best on Sunday, July , the pairrsquos chat show style programme.They appeared on the show, presented by father-and-son duo Martin and Roman Kemp, thanks to Maryrsquos six-hour TikTok dance marathon, which she completed on VE Day in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.Karen, a board member at the foundation, said: ldquoI got a message on Facebook from a producer at Cactus TV [an independent TV production company which owns runs the show], they were looking for inspirational families for the show.ldquoI was a wee bit unsure at first but the girl we spoke to was nice.ldquoThey saw Maryrsquos story online, I think it was the Courier online, and askedthey could give us a phone call.ldquoSo we had a couple of phone calls with them and they found out what happened and about the charity etc, like a pre-interview.ldquoRoman is also a big TikTok fan so he was really interested.The show was filmed on June  and took about one hour and  minutes in total to record. It was broadcast on STV ITV at .am last Sunday morning, July .As well as chats with actor and Spandau Ballet member Martin Kemp and his radio DJ and Irsquom a Celebrity... Get Me Out Of Here! star son Roman, the family played some games and spoke to the showrsquos three guests Laura Whitmore, Beverly Knight and Jessie Ware.Karen said: ldquoWe just had normal chats with them, they made us feel very, very welcome. title: mum-says-i-literally-begging-people-save-life
story: Trudie Murphy is hoping to fly out to the USA for treatment which could see the tumour removed.She was given the horrible news last week that specialists in Scotland would be unable to remove the cancerous tumour, while chemotherapy was also not an option.Doctors have said that she could receive radiotherapy but it would be as a last resort to extend her le.Now, a close friend, Colin ndash that is my sole driving force.ldquoThis GoFundMe page, I feel embarrassed because I feel like it is begging but I thought: lsquoI am literally begging for people to save my le so that I am here for my kids.rsquoldquoRight now, I just feel like somebody has put a plastic bag over my head and is slowly tightening it and I cannot breathe.ldquoIt is the last thing you think about at night and mum to Joshand Naomi , who attend Ross High School, Zak , who will be starting at Knox Academy Meadowpark, and eight-year-old Archie, who attends Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, in Tranent, saying she ldquofelt numb after being told she had an inoperable brain tumour.A biopsy and chemotherapy have both been ruled out by experts due to the location of the tumour.She said: ldquoThey donrsquot know how aggressive it is because they cannot do the biopsy.ldquoThey were throwing everything at me ndash there are  types of brain cancer. They donrsquot know how quick it is going to grow.ldquoIrsquove been told I will start to have epileptic fits, I will lose my mobility and even simple things like swallowing I will be unable to do.With options on the NHS limited, Trudie and her husband Dave, who tied the knot  months ago, are looking at the possibility of travelling to America or other countries for treatment.Trudie, who has lived in Tranent for about eight years after previously living in Musselburgh, where she attended the townrsquos secondary school, said a hospital in America could use a needle ldquoas thin as a hair to take a biopsy, while the possibility of operating on the tumour had not been ruled out.Unfortunately, that would mean raising thousands of pounds to cover expensive medical bills.Friends and family rallied round for the online appeal, with more than pound, already raised.Trudie, , encouraged people to get in touch with raffle prizes for a future fundraiser and said: ldquoPeople can surprise you.ldquoIt is not always the people you are closest to that reach out but people I have not spoken to for a while that reach out to you."There are strangers I have never met that are donating money to somebody that they donrsquot know, especially just now because of lockdown.ldquoEverybody has been affected by this financially one way or another and I certainly did not expect to get over pound,.Dave, who works as a residential childcare worker in Ormiston, described the news as ldquodevastating.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is hard to put it into words."She is so young, has so much to give and has so much to look forward to for this to potentially take her away, knowing potentially that something can be done ndash there are no words.To support Trudie, go to gofundme f treatment-for-trudie

title: world-famous-singer-pops-east-lothian-cafe
story: Sam visited JoLi, based in The Old Reading Rooms on Longniddryrsquos Main Street.Sam is said to have bought a coffee and some gts, with those at the cafe saying that the Grammy Award-winner stopped off on their travels to North Berwick.Staff at JoLi were ldquoa little bit starstruck when the singer popped by, saying the visit was ldquosomething you do not expect.They described the singer as a ldquolovely guy.A post sharing the news of the visit on social media has attracted a lot of attention from starstruck fans, with one fellow diner saying that she was in having lunch at the time and did not recognise the star.Sam, , is a British singer-songwriter who emerged onto the music scene in .Since then the musician, who delayed the release of their third album, has had several number one and top  hits in both the UK and US, and in  released Writingrsquos on the Wall, the theme song for the James Bond film Spectre.As well as Grammy Awards, Sam has won Brit Awards, Billboard Music Awards, American Music Awards, a Golden Globe and an Academy Award.It is believed Sam is on holiday in East Lothian with his family.

title: coronavirus-scotrail-offers-free-travel-unemployed----even-get-job
story: The coronavirus pandemic has had a huge impact on jobs in Scotland, with figures in May suggesting the number of people claiming unemployment benefit has increased by .% - up about , to ,.The travel firm say that the cost of travelling to an interview can ldquooften be a barrier to ing to work ndash so launched a scheme to fast-track the process.The idea was launched in , but has recently been marketed againby ScotRailas a result of the coronavirus.What can jobseekers get Those eligible can get two freejourneys a month to attend an interview.They can also then get a free ScotRail travel ticket for the first month of theirto work.Jobseekers are also able to take advantage of the Jobcentre Plus Travel Discount Card - a UK Government initiative which allows those who are unemployed and claiming Jobseekerrsquos Allowance or Universal Credit to receive a % discount on selected rail tickets.If youre out of work, were offering two free tickets per month for travel to interviews - as well as a free one month ticket once you secure a job.Am I eligible for the scheme To be eligible for any of these offers, the customer must have been claiming Jobseekers Allowance or Universal Credit for - monthsor - months .How does it work Tickets for travel to interview:For jobseekers to obtain up to two freetickets per month to attend interviews, their local Job Centre issues them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a local station where staff will issue a ticket .One month ticket once employment secured:If the jobseeker secures employment and wishes to apply for a free monthrsquos ticket, their local Job Centre will issue them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a station where staff will issue a ticket .What does ScotRail say ScotRail Alliance Managing Director Alex Hynes said: ldquoFor people out of work, the cost of travelling to an interview can often be a barrier to ing to work.ldquoBy removing that barrier and providing help with the cost, we hope to be able to support people into work and grow Scotlandrsquos economy.ldquoThe support we offer to jobseekers is one of the ScotRail Alliancersquos best kept secrets ndash but I want as many people as possible to know about this opportunity.

title: pubs-busy-open-first-time-months
story: Scottish Government-imposed restrictions to help fight the coronavirus pandemic were relaxed last week, with customers allowed back inside pubs, provided they followed social distancing.Businesses throughout the county were pleased to welcome back thirsty punters, with each reporting a busy weekend.Laura McSweeney, from The Green in Haddington, was pleased with how the weekend had gone.She said people had been ldquorespectful of the restrictions in place and the beer garden was proving popular, with the exception of during poor weather.She added: ldquoIt has been a bit of a mixture to be honest. The usual suspects are coming back but it has been a bit of an unusual time as people are heading back to work.ldquoOverall, we have had a lot more people come in for food and there has been quite a good turnout.Social distancing restrictions are in place at the Court Street pub, with signs reminding people of the restrictions.Meanwhile, staff are wearing visors when serving customers both inside and outside the building.Hand sanitiser is also available, with a strict cleaning schedule in place for the toilets as well.Victoria Fowler, at Musselburghrsquos Sportsman Bar, described trade as ldquoabsolutely brilliant over the weekend.She told the Courier: ldquoIt was much better than we expected.ldquoEverybody seems to be following the rules.ldquoWe were full all the time and having to turn people away.Despite the restrictions, Victoria said the pub, on the townrsquos High Street, had been busy.As well as social distancing, bar stools have been removed, while customers are not allowed to bring their empty glasses back to the bar.Similar to The Green, there is also a rigorous cleaning regime in place as well.William Gordon, manager at The Brig Inn in Tranent, said the beer garden had been full and there had been a good number of visitors.He added that ious restrictions had also been put in place but people seemed to be enjoying themselves.Chief Inspector Neil Mitchell, local area commander, had attended Haddingtonrsquos community council, which was held online, last week.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the group, asked what measures police were putting in place ahead of the first weekend of people drinking inside pubs.The senior officer said that licensing officers had liaised with each of the licensed premises across East Lothian ahead of them reopening.He noted that many were simply too small to have a great number of visitors when social distancing was taken into account and officers would be out over the weekend.He said: ldquoRight through the whole of East Lothian, [licensed premises] are really keen to make sure they provide a safe environment for customers.ldquoIf they do that, there will be far less people within their premises.ldquoWe will deal with any complaints in the normal manner.Writing in his Courier column this week, Ch Insp Mitchell was pleased to say that the weekend had gone smoothly.He wrote: ldquoOur licensed premises and restaurants re-opened in line with the Scottish Government guidance and I am really pleased to say that we had no incidents reported and everyone enjoyed themselves sensibly.

title: great-grandmother-celebrates-95th-birthday-95-plus-cards
story: Betty Sneddonwas delighted when relatives paid her a visit on Sunday to wish her many happy s and enjoy a socially distanced party in the garden of her town centre home.She did not want any gts but her family thought it would be a great ideashe received  cards ndash reflecting her age ndash from well-wishers.The number of cards sent has now surpassed the target as relatives and friends, some from abroad, inundated her with birthday messages, much to her surprise and amazement.During the Covid- lockdown, Mrs Sneddon enjoyed spending time in her beloved garden. She was also grateful to a friend who left cakes for her and gave her a wave.Her daughter Mary Blair kept her in touch with family via FaceTime but she was delighted to catch up with them in person on her birthday amid the easing of restrictions.The last surviving member of a family of nine ndash five brothers and four sisters ndash Mrs Sneddon was born in Musselburghrsquos Newbigging, where she first attended school.She was a pupil at Burgh Primary School and went on to secondary school at Fisherrow. She also lived for a time in Kilwinning.On leaving school, she was employed as a housemaid at Inveresk for a short time and also worked at Bruntonrsquos Wire Mill, Musselburgh. She also enjoyed working at LrsquoAperit, a restaurant in Edinburgh.She met her future husband Jimmy Sneddon when he was staying in lodgings in Musselburgh while working as a steel erector at Portobello Power Station. The couple were married at Inveresk Manse and set up home on Moir Avenue.Mrs Sneddon was a soprano and soloist in the famous Musselburgh Fishwives Choir.They sang all over the country and once went to sing for soldiers in recovery after the Second World War at Peel Hospital near Peebles. Her older brother Jim was recovering at the hospital from a severe back injury.A mum of three, grandmother of five and great grandmother of three, she has always filled her le with family and friends.Over the years, she enjoyed attending the Womenrsquos Rural Institute and playing Scrabble with Nancy Herkes, her best friend from school, until they were in their late seventies.A fan of detective programmes and brain-teasers, she said her recipe for a long and happy le was ldquocrosswords, Scrabble, gardening and great grandchildren keep you going ndash not forgetting Morse, Poirot and, of course, good genes.

title: tantallon-dirleton-castles-reopen-within-weeks
story: Dirleton Castle and Tantallon Castle, near North Berwick, have been closed to visitors by Historic Environment Scotlandduring the coronavirus pandemic.Now, restrictions are easing and Scotlandrsquos biggest operator of visitor attractions has revealed ldquoa phased approach to reopen  per cent of its free-to-access and ticketed properties by mid-September.HESrsquo website lists both Dirleton Castle and Tantallon Castle among  sites which it hopes to start opening from late August onwards ldquoon a rolling basis.ldquoThese sites will open in consultation with the local communities and reflecting circumstances in each area as much as possible, the website states.Alex Paterson, chief executive of HES, said: ldquoAt the forefront of our planning is the safety of our staff and visitors, whilst being able to reopen for the tourist season by gradually enabling safe access to our properties and facilities in line with Scottish Government guidance.ldquoWersquove been working exceptionally hard to ensure our properties will be accessible and ready to welcome visitors however, itrsquos important that we implement our resumption plans at the right time given the dferent requirements for each site.ldquoThis also includes looking at the ying local and regional requirements throughout the country and we have considered this when setting out our phased approach to welcoming visitors back and supporting Scotlandrsquos tourism and economic recovery.From last Wednesday, HES provided access to more than  unstaffed and key-keeper sites across Scotland, where physical distancing can be readily maintained and where HES can provide free and safe access.When the attractions reopen, visitors, including members, will be required to pre-book tickets online and use contactless payment where possible one-way systems will be implemented in some locations and some areas of sites, such as enclosed spaces, will be closed off.Visitor numbers will also be limited for safety reasons.Mr Paterson added: ldquoWersquore very much looking forward to welcoming visitors back.ldquoThere will of course be some initial changes, including managing visitor numbers at certain sites, as well as restricting access to specic locations, but we can assure visitors of a warm welcome.ldquoWe want to ask our visitors to help create a safe environment by behaving responsibly and following our guidance at properties, and we will be providing further information on our website for visitors to help them prepare for their visit.For more information, visit historicenvironment.scot

title: impressive-turnout-farmers-market-returns-town
story: The market ed to the townrsquos Court Street last Saturday, July , with an impressive turnout.Now, it is getting ready toagain tomorrow .The visitor numbers were revealed by Councillor John McMillan, who represents Haddington on East Lothian Council.The local authorityrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism told members of the townrsquos community council: ldquoAt the farmersrsquo market,  people came in, which is good for the town centre.The popular markets, which sell locally sourced products, had disappeared from the town for four months due to the coronavirus pandemic.However, the organisers worked with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland, among other groups, to see the marketon July .Steps were taken to ensure public safety at the event, with the introduction of a one-way system on Court Street.Visitors to the market entered beside the Corn Exchange before heading towards Brewery Lane and then turning back and leaving through a signed exit.Members of Haddington Rotary Club acted as stewards, while a headcount was also taken.The one-way system will remain in place for Saturdayrsquos market, with a total of  stalls expected to be open.Similarly, hand sanitising stations and stewards will again be on hand to try to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.Val Shields, chair of Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, was delighted to say the ing market had proven a great success.She told the Courier: ldquoI think everybody was pleased with it.ldquoIt was a nice relaxed atmosphere.ldquoPeople all did the things they were meant to do and were very patient and kept social distances.ldquoStallholders were quite happy to be back and takings were reasonable overall.ldquoThe weather was nice and everything aligned.ldquoIt was just a good day and everyone ndash customers and stallholders ndash was glad to be back.

title: plans-new-sports-pavilion-north-berwick-get-go-ahead
story: It will be located on land north-east of Wotherspoon Green and have an adjacent car park with  spaces, two of which will be for electric vehicles, with a charger point, and three for disabled users.Final plans for the car park area changed slightly from initial designs, including the entrance to the car park being moved and a path that led to the building removed.The interior of the single-storey building has not changed and will contain two changing rooms, each with a separate shower and toilet, two toilets, a plant room, storage cupboard, clubroom and accessible toilet.There will also be two bike racks.The application received six objections, all of which related to loss of privacy, loss of daylight, concerns relating to the use of floodlights, the buildingrsquos visual appearance, an increase in road traffic and pedestrians, and increase in noise at anti-social hours.The sports pavilion, which could be named after the late Pilmar Smith ndash a North Berwick legend who was former vice-chairman of Heart of Midlothian Football Club and former chairman of Lothian Buses ndash will not have floodlights.A council planning officerrsquos report said: ldquoThe sports pavilion is directly related to the future provision of the sports pitch to the south and would serve as a recreational facility for North Berwick and the existing and future residents of the wider Mains Farm development site.It is not known when work will begin on the building due to the current coronavirus restrictions.

title: community-resilience-groups-cockenzie-port-seton-dunbar-gullane-haddington-humbie-musselburgh-north-berwick-prestonpans-tranent-elphinstone-work-hard
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at nine of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonWHILE work goes on to wind down the resilience effort and prepare the community in Cockenzie and Port Seton for le after lockdown, volunteers have continued to provide assistance and receive donations.The local resilience effort has been led by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, which has this week continued to pay tribute to its volunteers on social media.The craft club at Chalmers Memorial Church has been making masks and donated some to the resilience team.Meanwhile, local people, including those in Longniddry, can visit the pantry at Port Seton Centre for food and other items.Delivery is also available by phoning the centre on  .Throughout lockdown, East Lothian Council staff at the centre have been making meals and, alongside resilience volunteers, delivering them to residents.Thanks was also given from Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership to Scotmid for the donation of deodorant and body wash it gave to the centre when it went to pick up toiletries for the pantry.The resilience effort will wind down either at the end of the month or when children go back to school in August.Contact detailsTo contact the Cockenzie and Port Seton resilience team, call  .DunbarDunbarCOMMUNITY resilience volunteers in Dunbar are getting ready to hand over the reins to East Lothian Council.Volunteers from throughout the town and neighbouring West Barns have been working to support vulnerable members of the two communities.The community resilience team will take a step back at the end of the month.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, said a lot of volunteers were already stepping away due to work commitments or to go on holiday.He said: ldquoIrsquove found it to be in some ways quite rewarding because it was very gratying to see what a positive response we had from the local community and how people stepped forward as volunteers."This started in mid-March when we set up those teams, we have come a long way now.
